case_vignette: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of a pruritic skin rash on his chest. His mother says that he has no history of dermatological problems. He was born at term and has been healthy except for recurrent episodes of otitis media. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 102/62 mm Hg. Examination shows vesicles and flaccid bullae with thin brown crusts on the chest. Lateral traction of the surrounding skin leads to sloughing. Examination of the oral mucosa shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count is within the reference range.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a really itchy skin rash on my chest.
How long have you had this skin rash?
I've had the skin rash for 3 days.
Do you have any other symptoms along with the rash, such as fever or fatigue?
I look pale, but I don't have a fever.
Do you have any known allergies? If so, to what?
No, I don't have any history of allergies.
Have you started using any new skincare products or detergents recently?
My mother says I have no history of dermatological problems, so we haven't changed anything recently.
Do you take any medications or have any medical conditions?
I've been healthy except for getting ear infections often.
Thank you for the information. Any family history of skin conditions, like eczema or psoriasis?
There's no history of skin problems in my family.
**Final Diagnosis:** Allergic contact dermatitis
